column4: I've got a harddrive (VFAT) mounted to /mnt.  The permissions are set so only the owner can write to it.  When I do: sudo chmod 777 /mnt it prompts for my password, but nothing happens and the permissions don't change.  Any idea what I'm doing wrong?
vfat doesn't have permissions, so you can't set them
VFAT doesn't have permissions?  I'm not sure I understand ... I formatted the disk using disk writer, now I just want to copy data to it off my internal hard drive ...
vfat is a pretty simple fs - it does not store permission information for every file, as ext2 or ntfs do. linux kind of "emulates" permissions when you mount a vfat volume
the permissions used can be set in /etc/fstab

I've got it formated as VFAT right now, but ubuntu says that only the "owner" (root) has permission to write to it.  There isn't an owner account on ubuntu, so I don't know how to copy from my directory to the disk ... I believe I need to change the permissions on the disk (mounted at /mnt) ... but sudo chmod 777 /mnt doesn't do anything ...
could you tell my the corresponding line for the disk in /etc/fstab?
#/dev/hdb1 /media/hdb1 ntfs ro,user,fmask=0133,dmask=0022,uid=1000,gid=1000 0 0
Wait, that's not it
I don't see a line in fstab that corresponds to it.  What I did was: System -> Administration -> Disks ... Formatted the Disk to VFAT and set the mountpoint there to /mnt
run "mount" once to see which dev the hd mounted at /mnt is
then "sudo umount /mnt"
/dev/hdb1 on /mnt type vfat (rw)
Okay, it's not longer mounted
then remount it with 'sudo mount -o "defaults,user,uid=0,gid=1000,umask=002" /dev/hdb1 /mnt'
I did that, but it still tells me no permissions (I'm trying to drag a folder I "own" into the /mnt directory)
which gid does your user have?
hm that's strange - i have the exact same mount parameters for a vfat drive here and can write to it, no problems
Strange ... I have no idea what to do :(
ok, umount hdb1 again and try this: mount -o "rw,nosuid,noexec,nodev,uid=1000,gid=1000,umask=77" /dev/hdb1 /mnt
